direction.raw_text: On a dark screen an immense amber light appears and an electric humming begins. The eerie light glows brighter and illuminates a single huge number--11. We hear static and a large vertical band of red floats mysteriously across the screen. Pulling back slowly, we watch the glowing band traverse back and forth over the amber light and past more numbers appearing--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... 90... 110... 130. And we begin to hear voices--strange songs, fading conversations and snatches of music drifting with static. Pulling back further, we realize it is a car radio filling the screen and radio stations we're hearing, until the indicator stops. There's a pause...and suddenly we are hit by a blasting-out-of-the-past, Rocking and Rolling, turn-up- the-volume, pounding Intro to a Vintage 1962 Golden Week-End Radio Show--back when things were simpler and the music was better. And now a wolf howl shatters through time as the legendary Wolfman Jack hits the airwaves, his gravel voice shrieking and growling while the music pumps and grinds...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Wolfman howls like a soulful banshee as "Rock Around the Clock" blasts forth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Awwrigght, baay-haay-baay! I got a oldie for ya--gonna knock ya right on de flowa--baay-haay-hee-baay!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A neon drive-in casts long shadows across a vast parking lot as the sun drops behind a distant hill. A large neon sign buzzes in the foreground... MEL'S DRIVE-IN, while in the background, "Rock Around The Clock" blares from the radio of a beautiful decked and channeled, white with red trim, tuck- and-rolled '58 Chevy Impala that glides into the drive-in. Main titles appear over action. Steve Bolander stops the elegant machine and gets out. He looks around, then walks to the front of the car and leans against the flame-covered hood. Steve is eighteen, good-looking in a conservative, button-down, short-sleeved shirt. Most likely to succeed, president of his graduating class. He looks around the empty drive-in, then hears a funny little horn. A Vespa scooter bumps into the lot. A young kid waves at him-- and suddenly grabs the handlebars again as the scooter nearly topples. Terry Fields ("The Toad") maneuvers the scooter next to Steve's Chevy but misjudges and ricochets off the trash can before stopping. Terry grins sheepishly. He's seventeen, short but plenty loud, both vocally and sartorically in his pink and black shirt, levis, and white bucks. He looks slightly ridiculous but always thinks he's projecting an air of supercool. Steve watches Terry smooth back his shiny ducktail and primp his waterfall to a perfect cascade over his forehead. He unbuttons his shirt one more button and lowers his pants to look tough. Terry walks over and leans against the flamed car, imitating Steve who pays him no mind. In the background, we hear the Wolfman howling with the music. The record ends and a barrage of humor begins from Wolfman Jack. The Wolfman is an unseen companion to all the kids. Witty and knowledgeable about the trivia that counts, he's their best friend, confidant, and guardian angel. Now, a grey, insect-like Citroen deux-chevaux putters into the parking lot and stops on the other side of the lot. Steve and Terry watch Curt Henderson get out. Curt stands by his little car. He's seventeen, a curly bespectacled, scraggly kid with a summer-grown moustache and a paperback stuck in his bermuda shorts. Curt thinks of himself as the town cynic. In reality, he's a hopeless romantic. He starts over to his buddies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve reaches into his pocket and hands Curt an envelope without saying anything. Curt opens it slowly and pulls out a check.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve looks at Curt suspiciously; Curt seems somehow guilty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt hands the envelope back to Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly a horn honks and they all turn. Laurie Henderson pulls into the drive-in and waves to them. She is driving the family's '58 Edsel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie honks the horn a couple of times. Steve ignores her. There is a long moment and Curt looks uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, there's an ear-splitting roar and they all turn as a yellow '32 Ford deuce coupe--chopped, lowered and sporting a Hemi-V8--bumps into the lot. The low slung classic rumbles and parks at the rear of the drive in. Big John Milner, twenty-two, sits in his Ford, tough and indifferent, puffing on a Camel. He wears a white T-shirt and a butch haircut molded on the sides into a ducktail. A cowboy in a deuce coupe--simple, sentimental and cocksure of himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve walks off toward Laurie's Edsel. Laurie gets out. She's wearing a letterman's sweater with a large "Class of '62" emblazoned on the shoulder. Steve goes to her and they hug. On the radio, the music ends, and the Wolfman's intro tune comes on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, whadaya say? Curt? Last night in town, you guys gonna have a little bash before you leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Moose have been lookin' for you all day, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Oh great...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whadaya got, whadaya got? Wow--two thousand dollars. Two thousand doll-- !!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Jenning couldn't find you, so he gave it to me to give to you. He said he's sorry it's so late, but it's the first scholarship the Moose Lodge has given out. Oh yeah, he says they're all very proud of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... ah... why don't you hold onto it for a while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's with you? It's yours! Take it! I don't want it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve... Ah, I think we'd better have a talk. I've gotten-
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your sister calls. I'll talk to you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Steve! Let her wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, make it short and sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well... Listen... (clearing his throat) I... I don't think I'm going tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What! Come on, what are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I was thinking I might wait for a year... go to city--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You chicken fink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait, let me explain--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't back out now! After all we went through to get accepted. We're finally getting out of this turkey town and now you want to crawl back into your cell--look, I gotta talk to Laurie. (he hands the check back to Curt) Now take it. We're leaving in the morning. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanna end up like John? You can't stay seventeen forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just want some time to think. What's the rush? I'll go next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll talk later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing) "Here comes the Wolfman--Wolfman Jack!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Oh, We're gonna rock and roll ourselves to death baby. You got the Wolfman Jack Show!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the radio blares "Sixteen Candles," we see that with the darkness Burger City has come alive. A continual line of hot rods pulls into the parking lot to check out the parked cars, then returns to the maindrag. Carhops glide by on roller skates. Curt and John are fooling around in front of the deuce coupe. A horn honks and they turn as a '60 Ford with three girls in it slows by them. A girl leans out the window and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls in the car all screech and giggle as they zoom off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John watches the procession of gleaming cars traveling through the hot night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, in the distance, there's a blood-curdling scream from an incredible high-performance engine. The entire drive- in stops and listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Across the swarming parking lot, Steve sits in the front seat of his chevy with Laurie. Budda Macrae, a car hop, leans down to attach a tray to Steve's window, showing off her tight blouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She tucks in her blouse a little tighter, gives him a hot look and goes to get the other tray. Budda takes the other tray around the car, almost shoves it in the window where Laurie is sitting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives Laurie an antagonistic look and goes off. Steve laughs. Laurie smiles. She's seventeen, very pretty, with big doe-eyes, and a short bobbed hairdo. She pushes up the sleeves on Steve's letterman sweater, which is sizes too large for her. His class ring glints on a chain around her neck. Laurie is sweet, the image of vulnerability, but with a practical and self-preserving mind beneath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the windshield of the Chevy, they see Terry run by in front of them, chasing Budda Macrae who's outdistancing him on her roller skates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve watches them go by, then looks back at Laurie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie pretends to be interested in her french fries, but is obviously expecting something big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie hasn't looked up but her mood has changed like a mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve smiles and then looks to her. He stops smiling. They listen to the radio for an awkward moment. Laurie struggles to hold back her tears. With obvious difficulty, she turns to him and smiles. He's expected something different and doesn't know what to do, so he smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie takes his ring on the chain from around her neck and puts it in her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve just looks at her and nods. The Wolfman howls an intro to "Gee" by the Crows. Outside, skooting around the drive-in after Budda, Terry is pleading with the sexy car hop as she delivers a tray to a car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her tone changes immediately. Terry looks sour and turns around to Steve who's getting out of the chevy. Budda leaves, wiggling her butt for Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve notices Terry isn't with him any more and turns. Terry is standing frozen to a spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry tries to talk, much like a shell-shocked war veteran. His mouth moves but only a gurgle comes out. Curt is standing by the Chevy, talking with his sister Laurie. She's still upset by what Steve said to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, they watch Terry as Steve explains to him about the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others are watching now as Terry shakes his head mechanically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is indeed a tear rolling down Terry's cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie watches Terry, realizing that like the car, she'll be left behind as a fond memory. She turns and looks at Steve, who's been watching her. There's a moment between them... Budda comes by with an empty tray. Terry sees her and wipes his eyes. He walks up to her, a strange look on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The idea is so preposterous that even Budda is speechless. She looks around at others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John walks up quietly and casually pulls down hard on the back pockets of Terry's low riding levis. There is general hysteria as Terry quickly pulls up his pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John walks angrily to his coupe, gets in and slams the door. Curt looks at the others and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt goes over and stands by the window of the yellow coupe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John looks at him suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John shakes his head. On the radio, Wolfman is taking a call from a listener--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John roars his engine and pulls the yellow deuce coupe into a screeching take-off out of the drive-in. Terry and Curt watch him go off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi John!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not too good, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is it every girl that comes around here is ugly? Or has a boyfriend? Where is the dazzling beauty I've been searching for all my life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you mean. The pickin's are really gettin' slim. The whole strip is shrinking. Ah, you know, I remember about five years ago, take you a couple of hours and a tank full of gas just to make one circuit. It was really somethin.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, John. Someone new in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ahhh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gonna go after him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, listen, Professor, if he can't find me, then he ain't worth racin', right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The big shot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A cherry-vanilla coke and a chocolate mountain. Anything else you want, Steve? (Steve shakes his head.) If there is you let me know now. Just honk and I'm yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One fries--grab it before I drop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where was I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um, how you thought high school romances were goofy and we started going together just because you thought I was kinda cute and funny, but then you suddenly realized you were in love with me, it was serious... and ah... oh, you were leadin' up to somethin' kinda big.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make it sound like I'm giving dictation. Well, seriously, what I meant was, that ah... since we do care for each other so much, and since we should really consider ourselves as adults. Now, I, ah... could I have a couple of those fries?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : Come on, Budda. Come on...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, where was I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ..."consider ourselves adults"...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right... right... anyway, I thought maybe, before I leave, we could ah... agree that... that seeing other people while I'm away can't possibly hurt, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean dating other people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it would strengthen our relationship. Then we'd know for sure that we're really in love. Not that there's any doubt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're right. I mean, we're not kids anymore, and it's silly to think that when we're three thousand miles apart we shouldn't be able to see other people and go out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Laurie, now, listen, I didn't ask for that back. I think that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. I just sort of think it's juvenile now. I'll keep it at home. It's less conspicuous there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to wear it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say that. I understand and I'm not upset. I mean, I can't expect you to be a monk or something while you're away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and I have a really sharp record collection. I even have "Pledging My Love" by Johnny Ace. Anyway, how can you love Nelson when he's going out with Marilyn Gator. Since he dumped on you maybe we could--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't dump on me, you little dip. Hi, Steve!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a little conceited--just playing hard to get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I came over here to talk to you about--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any time, buddy. I'm your man. Nothing I like better than chewing the rug with a pal. You talk, I'll listen. I'm all ears. Shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terry, I'm going to let you take care of my car while we're away--at least until Christmas. I'm afraid if I leave it with my--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, sis--what's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now listen, only 30 weight Castrol- R. I've written the tire pressure and stuff on a pad in the glove compartment. Are you listening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong, he's crying!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't... believe... it. (He starts toward the car and gently caresses its paint.) I don't know what to say. I'll... love and protect this car until death do us part. (He circles the car.) This is a superfine machine. This may even be better than Daryl Starbird's superfleck moonbird. It is better than Daryl Starbird's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Budda, how would you like to go to the drive-in movies with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to be kidding!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would I kid you about a thing like that? I want you to know that something has happened to me tonight that is going to change everything. I've got a new...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Car!! All right, who's the wise-- (He turns and sees John and changes his tune.) Oh, John--verrry funny. (He tries to laugh with the others.)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, did she do that to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's get going. It seems like we've spent most of our lives in this parking lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Curt, let's bomb around, I wanna try out my new wheels!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to, Toad, but I'm going with Steve and Laurie to the hop. I'd just slow you down anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, tonight things are going to be different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait a minute, you're goin' to the Hop? The Freshman Hop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, come on, man. That place is for kids. You two just got your ass out of there. Don't go back now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ain't got no emotions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're gonna remember all of the good times, is what we're gonna do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you come with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bullshit, man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. For old time's sake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, yeah... Well, listen. You go. Go ahead, Curtsy, baby. You go on over there and you remember all the good times you won't be having. I ain't goin' off to some goddamned fancy college. I'm stayin' right here. Havin' fun, as usual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Milner, you're in a great mood tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter John? Did I say somethin' wrong? I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, man, it's nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we'll see you later, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll all do somethin' together. You know, before Steve leaves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, wait a minute. Now, you're not going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Wolfman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Who is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Joe... in Little Rock, way down in the Valley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You callin' from Little Rock, California?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long distance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My, my, my... listen, man, what kind of entertainment you got in that town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All we got is you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: During the day, G street is a line of used car lots, small shops, tacky department stores and greasy spoons. At night, it is transformed into an endless parade of kids in flamed, lowered and customed machines who rumble down the one way street, through the seemingly adultless, heat-drugged little town. Police cars glide ominously with the flow of traffic. In parked cars, couples neck between flashing headlights. Guys looking cool in a '56 Chevy sit in the slouched position of the true Low Rider--and over it all the music and the Wolfman can be heard. Just now, it's "Runaway" by Del Shannon. John travels with the flow of traffic, watching some dopey guys shooting squirt guns from a moving car. John drives the deuce coupe effortlessly. He looks over at a car pacing alongside of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sweaty looking guy turns and nods from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John nods and the two cars pull apart down the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Zudo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Milner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, man, what happened to your flathead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to your flathead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, your mother!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mother. Hey, we been talkin' about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. There's a very wicked '55 Chevy lookin' for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Watch out for the cop that's in Jerry's Cherry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. All right, thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Rock and Roll blares as Terry the Toad cruises along the main drag, singing along with the music. Sitting low in his seat, he looks around, his face aglow, experiencing a new world from the inside of a really fine car. This is the greatest thing that has happened to Terry in seventeen long years of being a short loser. Terry turns a corner and another car pulls alongside. A guy looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry looks over and smiles coolly, proud of his new wheels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry's smile changes to a scowl as the car pulls away from him.. Terry accounts the slight to jealousy. Then he forgets it and enjoys driving the beautiful Chevy again. Another car pulls alongside of him as he cruises along slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry looks over at the car cruising next to him. In the back seat, a guy has dropped his trousers and is pushing his bare buttocks against the side window--a classic BA complete with pressed ham. Terry looks away, wondering why this is still happening to him, even in his new car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Toad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning out the window) Is that you in that beautiful car? (Terry nods modestly) Geez, what a waste of machinery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Curt is in the back seat gazing out the window at the dark main street of the small farm community. Steve and Laurie are talking quietly in the front seat. Laurie is sitting near the window and it sounds like Steve is convincing her to move over. Laurie finally does. His arm goes around her and her head rests on his shoulder. Curt is laughing as the Wolfman harasses someone on the radio. The Wolfman is placing a call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wolfman cuts into "Why Do Fools Fall in Love." Curt is laughing in the back of the car, as he listens to the ever- present D.J. Steve slows the Edsel to a stop at the next light. Curt glances over at a classic white '56 Thunderbird and sits up. In the T-bird, a girl watches him. Blonde, beautiful, her hair, backlit by a used car lot, seems to glow, making her look almost ethereal. Curt doesn't move, as if afraid of scaring her away. She smiles faintly---then says something, so softly it's lost...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt struggles to lower his window. She repeats it, but he can't hear. The light changes. She smiles once more and is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt looks at his sister and Steve in the front seat. They are bored by his romantic visions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie looks around at him and seems to pity his flights of poetic fantasy. Curt sits back and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Here we go with another call out of the station. Can you dig it? Answer the phone, dummy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Pinkie's Pizza

dialogue.raw_text: Hit parade on the stethoscope?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No, the secret agent spy-scope, man. That pulls in the moon, the sky and the planets... and the satellites and the little bitty space men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must have the wrong number, partner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) What? What?!!!

dialogue.raw_text: We didn't say anything.

dialogue.raw_text: What? Why?

dialogue.raw_text: Cut over to G Street, I've just seen a vision! She was a goddess. You've got to catch her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't see anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not going to spend the night chasing girls for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm telling you, this was the most perfect, dazzling creature I've ever seen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's gone. Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She spoke to me. She spoke to me, right through the window. I think she said, "I love you."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That means nothing to you people? You have no romance, no soul? She-- someone wants me. Someone roaming the streets wants me! Will you turn the corner?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Big John sits in his deuce coupe, backed into the parking lot of the Acme Fall-out Shelter Co., the prime spot in town for girl watching. A guy in wrap-around dark glasses leans by the car next to John. They watch a group of laughing girls cruise by in a Studebaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John turns on his lights and swings the deuce coupe out into the flow of traffic, after the Studebaker. John accelerates and pulls alongside the Studebaker. The girl in the front seat rolls down her window. John grins and yells over at the carload of cuties.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girls chatter and giggle among themselves. One of the girls dangles a bra out the back window, and they all break into hysterical laughter. The girls try to accelerate ahead, but John stays alongside their car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small voice rises above the chatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first girl grins and nods. John winks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cars stop at the light. A girl rushes out from the Studey and runs around the back of John's coupe. She opens the door and climbs in fast as the light changes. The Studebaker pulls off fast. John pushes through the gears and turns and smiles at his pick-up, as "That'll Be the Day" plays on the Wolfman Jack Show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol Morrison shakes her head. She is thirteen years old, very cute--wearing blue jeans, sneakers and a "Dewey Webber Surf Board" T-shirt which hangs to her knees. John seems slightly panicked.

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, a car horn honks next to them. John looks over at the car.

direction.raw_text: John grabs Carol by the neck and pushes her head down onto his lap so she can't be seen. John casually waves to the friend in the car cruising alongside.

direction.raw_text: Carol's head is being held down on his lap. She looks up at him.

direction.raw_text: John jumps, and immediately lets go of her as if burned.

direction.raw_text: John is beginning to sweat now.

direction.raw_text: Terry continues to cruise the main drag, slouched low and looking cool in his newly acquired machine. He adjusts his waterfall curl as the Wolfman dedicates a list of songs. He passes a group of guys bullshitting around the raised hood of a souped-up parked car. Terry cruises alongside two girls in a Ford. He revs the engine to get their attention and once he has it he motions to roll down their window. They flip him the bird instead and he lets them pass. Terry pulls up to a stop light. The car next to him is a '56 Ford--a good opponent and besides, the kid driving looks younger than Terry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry revs his engine. So does the Ford. The tension mounts. The green arrow for the left turn lane flashes on, the car on Terry's other side moves off, and before he can control his reflexes, Terry, too, has shot into the intersection while the light remains red! Terry quickly shifts and returns to the starting position. The other driver is grinning. Terry is flustered and embarrassed. Terry revs the Chevy a couple more times, concentration intently this time on the right light. Green!... The Ford bolts into the intersection. Terry likewise floors the gas pedal and goes crashing backwards into a large Buick. Terry is stunned for a moment, then realizes he forgot to shift into first. He fumbles to get the car into first gear. A distinguished looking man comes up to his window after inspecting the damage. Terry tries to escape, but in his panic the engine dies. He struggles to start it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry roars off in a cloud of indignant smoke, leaving the gentleman standing in the street looking dismayed. The cars behind him begin to honk their horns and shout crudities.
direction.name: direction

A hundred of them are dancing and swaying while the band gyrates on a raised platform. Kids on wooden bleachers watch the whirling and spinning mass of ponytails and ducktails, button-down shirts and mid calf skirts, cardigan sweaters with little belts in the back.

direction.raw_text: Terry is looking and feeling like he's got it made. He downshifts and slows for a red light. A very mean-looking black '55 Chevy--blown, scooped and slicked--pulls up next to him. The driver, Bob Falfa, has a gum-chewing girlfriend sitting almost on top of him. Terry challenges the '55 Chevy by revving his engine. Bob Falfa doesn't even look over. He revs his engine--which sounds like a cross between a Boeing 707 and a SuperChief. Terry can't believe it. He quits revving his engine--feeling deflated. Terry looks over at the snotty grin on Falfa's girlfriends' face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry doesn't say anything and Bob Falfa glares over at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Falfa nods slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry doesn't say anything. There's another incredible scream as Falfa roars off, leaving Terry to stare through his smoke. Terry accelerates the '58 Chevy--at a prudent speed. As the radio blares "Almost Grown," Terry glides past the lighted stores slowly, taking in everything with wide eyes from his beautiful new car. Terry passes a steaming rear-end collision at an intersection where two guys and two girls are all yelling. Then, suddenly, he spots a girl--walking--alone. His mouth drops open in amazement as he slows to a crawl. Debbie, nineteen, with blonde hair, wearing a blue and white spaghetti- strap dress, strolls along the sidewalk. Terry rolls the powerful engine, but she ignores him. As he passes her, he speeds up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry tears around the corner and starts his approach once more. He quickly whips out his comb, touches up his hair and settles down into a comfortable slouch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hits the clutch, roars the engine a couple more times and then--disaster. Debbie passes behind some rough looking dudes on motorcycles, parked along the curb. One especially vicious biker turns and looks at Terry as he passes. Terry roars off around the block.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Debbie passes the bikers, they hoot, holler, and make barnyard noises. From the cat calls, and Debbie's manner it seems obvious that Debbie is a girl a lot of boys have "known." She has walked clear of the bikers as Terry screeches around the corner again. He pulls up alongside her and again slows to a crawl. The pass each other for awhile, but she doesn't look over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This stops her and she turns--Terry hits the brakes and the car bounces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debbie starts slowly toward the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry is elated. He climbs out of the car and she slides in the driver's side. Terry climbs back in next to her and slams the door. She's sitting right next to him--like a real date should. Terry gets a little nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry nods, checks his clutch, revs the engine to a high- pitched whine and they're off-- The tires smoke, scream, the car shots off, fish-tailing, nearly hitting a parked car, straightening out... and disappears down Main Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve gives a sick smile as she drags him out onto the floor. A record needle scratches and "Smoke Gets in Your Eyes" blares out as Steve and Laurie dance alone in the middle of the floor. The crowd quiets, getting a little misty about this soon-to-be separated teenage couple. For their part, Steve and Laurie are arguing, whispering in each other's ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes her hand from the tucked-under-the-chin position and puts it around him, in a bear-hug.

direction.raw_text: He moans.

direction.raw_text: They continue to dance slowly. Laurie starts to cry, hating herself for it. Steve loosens a minute and looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds her tighter and they circle the floor, all alone, the crowd watching quietly, the gym echoing with "Smoke Gets in Your Eyes."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: --a great band and they came all the way from Stockton. Let's hear it.

direction.raw_text: Curt is leaning against a car in the parking lot. He's looking up at the stars and listening to the music floating out from the gym.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pretty, dark-haired girl, Wendy, slides up next to him and leans against the car. There's an awkward pause like that which happens often when two people who used to be close meet after things have changed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A horn honks and Wendy turns to a VW that's idling nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go off toward the VW and climb in.

direction.raw_text: Terry not only looks cool now, but is cool, singing with the radio, a girl beside him. Hot stuff. Terry ever so slowly tries to put his arm around her, but by the time he manages it, he has to shift. They drive by some kids having a car-to-car water pistol war.

direction.raw_text: We see the white T-bird ahead for just a moment, before it accelerates, passes a car and disappears, as we hear "Peppermint Twist" from the radio. In the VW, Curt is in the back, shaking the driver's seat, yelling at Bobbie. Wendy is in front next to Bobbie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little VW swerves and cuts around an old dagoed Dodge, then speeds along the fast lane. Ahead, we catch a glimpse of the T-bird as it turns a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobbie turns, somebody honks, she hits the curb, shifting madly she mis-clutches; the beetle lugs forward; Curt falls back in the seat and Wendy looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are a few moments of silence as Bobbie lets Curt sweat it out. Finally, Curt breaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets in and the car goes off. In the back seat, Curt and Wendy are talking softly. He puts his arm around her and she makes a face, but doesn't remove it. Bobbie watches in the rear-view mirror, Curt sees her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt looks at her and turns her head. He kisses her and puts his arm around her. They neck. The radio plays "Barbara Ann." The little VW flashes by in the stream of traffic. Bobbie drives, glancing in here rear-view mirror occasionally and also watching the station wagon ahead, in which two pairs of feet are dancing against the back window. Wendy pulls away from Curt's lips and looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wendy turns and leans forward, laughing. Curt watches her seriously, studying her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pull up next to Kip's car and Curt leans forward and yells out Bobbie's window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bobbie swerves the car away and turns a corner. She stops on a dime at the curb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and starts flailing at Curt with her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wendy is laughing and Curt climbs over her out of the small car. He gets out and closes the door. Wendy changes seats and looks at him seriously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car pulls off and Curt watches it. Suddenly, he sees something--the T-bird going the other way down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The VW's gone and Curt starts after the T-bird on foot. He runs down the middle of the street, oblivious to the horns honking and the cars swerving to miss him. We move with Curt as he moves like a broken field runner through the traffic only to finally lose the girl and the Thunderbird and to slow and finally stop, standing on the white line. Cars slow down and kids rubberneck as they go by him.

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe.
