dialogue.raw_text: (from the front seat) Look, there's Kip Pullman! He's so neat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know Kip?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh? Yeah, I know him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Talk to him when we go by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want me to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything... I just want to meet him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kip, baby, what's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henderson, long time no see. Whadaya been doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much, just wanted to let you know that Bobbie here is hopelessly in love with you and trembles at the sight of your rippling biceps...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You creep, fink, son-of-a-bitch--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help, wait! Joke--Joke--Bobbie, remember your nose bleeds!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out--get out of my car--I hate you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me--ouch--Wendy--I got to go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Curt, I hope I see you at registration. Call me if you want. It was nice seeing you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shit--there!! Wait!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: John is driving and the Wolfman is howling on the radio while Carol is having the time of her life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the radio moans into "Who Wrote the Book of Love." Carol sits with her feet up against the dash. John knocks them off and she scowls at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John suddenly hits the brakes and Carol almost hits the floor. John reaches over and opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares at him, shaken, looking sweet and helpless. He turns and looks at her. A tear rolls down her cheek slowly. John can't take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol is delighted. She slams the door. John takes off.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CRUISING G STREET--'32 YELLOW DEUCE COUPE

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Went to a dance lookin' for romance. Found Barbara Ann... baby... Hey, this one is for all you out there watchin' the Submarine Races.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so thirsty, I could die. Just a little 10 cent coke to wet my whistle. It won't take a minute, I can drink it in the--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you just get out and get one then! So long, goodbye, hasta lumbago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, one coke and then home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't it great, the way I can cry whenever I want. A lot of people can't do that, but Vicki showed me how. I bet you can't cry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't count on it. I may surprise you any minute now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: John cruises around the lot until he finds a space among the rows of dazzling cars. He pulls in and leans out to hit the intercom button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks around, sitting up so maybe some of her friends will see her in John's neat car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long line of cars coast past. Occasionally, someone yells a greeting to John. The car hop brings the coke. Then a couple, Al and Linda, come over. They lean in the window smiling--John prays they don't see Carol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slugs John on the arm. John grabs her arm as she starts to swing again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She struggles to hit him and spills her coke all over the car. He pushes her rather roughly against the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is about to really cry this time. She jumps out of the car and runs off down the street. John wipes his car out as Al and Linda watch in amazement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John mutters profanities to himself, but his anger subsides after a few moments. He looks back in the direction Carol went. All he can see are two Hell's Angels on choppers rolling in the same direction. He looks a little concerned and starts the coupe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into intercom) One ten cent coke. Is ice extra? All right, ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh rats, I though some of my friends might be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably a couple of weeks past their bedtime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait, there's Dee Dee. I hope she sees me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Shit, Dee Dee!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hiya, John. Say, do you think if I brought my Mopar by the shop Monday you could spot weld the bumper bracket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have to be before noon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Hey, have you met Linda?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Hi--ahh, this is my, ahh, cousin, Carol. I'm kinda babysitting tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Babysitting!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus--watch it, will yuh? (smiling at Al) Been hittin' me all night. Kids will be kids, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Watch out--damn it! Look what--why don't you grow up! (looking at Al again) We don't get along too well. It's been like this--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You spastic creep!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't get along too well. You know what cousins are like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... well, I'll see ya on Monday before noon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: John roars along looking for her until he sees her walking angrily along the sidewalk--being followed by a Ford full of guys. John passes Carol and the Ford and pulls over and stops just ahead of them. Carol stops when she sees John. The Ford also stops and the guys call out to her. She considers the situation a moment, then runs and gets in with John. He pulls off and she grins at him happily.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CRUISING MAIN STREET--'32 YELLOW DEUCE COUPE

dialogue.raw_text: Hi cousin, how's your bod?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Terry pulls into the parking lot and stops. He looks up at the flashing liquor store sign and considers his battle plan. "Maybe Baby" by Buddy Holly is playing on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man regards him, Terry pretends to start off until the man goes in. Terry pulls himself together as another man approaches, or rather stumbles up, being older, scruffy and, essentially, a bum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bum is still trying to focus on Terry and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man takes the money and falls into the store. Terry watches and then waves to Debbie in the car that everything is cool. As he waits for the bum to come back out, the first man in the suit exits. Terry smiles at him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man gets into the car and backs out. Terry goes over to the window of the liquor store and looks to see how the wino's doing with his booze. Terry sees the liquor store owner setting four bottles of cheap wine on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner turns and sees Terry waving. Terry ducks out of sight. When he looks back again, Terry sees the old bum is gone! Terry can't believe it. He finally enters the store.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have an ID?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... hey, but no sweat. What'll it be? Beer, little wine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you could get some Old Harper, I'd give you a French kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Old Harper, rrright! He gives her an OK sign with his fingers and goes over to the store. He starts to enter, then stops and thinks. He sees a man in a business suit approaching, and smiles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir, while you're in there-- I mean, since you're going in anyway, I wonder if--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you--sir--could you give me the time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at his watch) Why sure, it's a quarter to twelve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. Quarter to twelve. Thanks a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pardon me, sir, but I lost my I.D. in--in a flood and I'd like to get some Old Harper, hard stuff. Would you mind buying a bottle for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why certainly, I lost my wife, too-- her name wasn't Idy, though, and it wasn't in a flood--but I know what ya--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, here's enough for a pint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. Still quarter to twelve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right-o. Night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gesturing through the window from outside) Hey, no. Not wine. Ssss--hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Terry tries to look very casual as he sidles up to the counter. Country-Western music hums over the liquor in hi- fi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry is destroyed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry looks at the man and the endless rows of liquor behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner puts everything into a bag and starts to ring it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner takes the liquor out of the bag and puts it back on the shelf. Terry stands there. The owner takes the money from him and gives him his change.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling at the owner) Hi there--ah, say--was there an old man in here a minute ago?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. He went out the back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah--ah--let me have a Three Musketeers, ah, and a ball point pen ther, a comp, a pint of Old Harper, couple of flashlight batteries and some of this beef jerky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, got an I.D. for the liquor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A what? Oh, sure-- (feeling his pockets) Oh nuts, I left it--I left it in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, you'll have to get it before--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can't. I also ah, forgot the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Terry comes back to the Chevy with the bag full of junk. Debbie smiles at him excitedly and scoots over to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her the bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes through the bag and finds a comb and the batteries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes the money from a squeeze-open plastic change purse and hands it to him. Terry smiles weakly and goes back to try his luck again at the liquor store. He stops in front of the door as a young guy with numerous tattoos on his bulging arms approaches the liquor store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes Terry's money and enters the store. The clerk hands the man a bottle of Old Harper. Terry waves excitedly to Debbie, lowering his pants a bit. Suddenly, there's a gunshot! Terry whirls to see the young man stuffing cash from the register into his pockets, backing away with a smoking gun. He rushes out of the store, tossing the bottle to Terry and running off into the night. Suddenly, the owner emerges from behind the counter, shooting wildly. Terry ducks and heads for the car with his pint of Old Harper.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, did ya get it? Ya get it, ya get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got it. You got it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't get it. Why didn't you get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, well, I needed some things and I thought as long as I was in there-- look, Debbie, can you loan me a dollar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Are you for real? Come on. Girls don't pay. Guys pay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, see--I've only got a fifty and he doesn't have change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can't believe this... I really cannot believe this. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi--excuse me. I was wondering--could you, ah--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Buy you a bottle of booze. Yeah, I know. You lost your I.D. What kind do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amazed) Gee, that's terrific. Ah, just some ah--Old Harper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: John's '32 deuce coupe crunches to a gravelly stop in front of a dark auto-wrecking yard. John and Carol get out and climb over the fence. They walk through a valley of twisted, rusting piles of squashed, mashed and crushed automobiles. John sticks his hand into his pockets moodily and stops and looks at one of the burnt-out cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John doesn't hear her and walks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol takes his hand and they walk a bit, until John realizes what he's doing, and drops her hand and pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stomps off and gets back into the coupe, quickly rolling up all the windows. John saunters up and finds the door locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John grins and starts to pull his keys out of his pocket. He stops grinning: Carol grins and dangles his keys inside the car. John leans against the window, closes his eyes, a defeated man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hears the button click up and slowly opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John gets into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Wolfman's gravelly voice whispers over the airwaves as John and Carol drive out of the shadowy car grave-yard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's Freddy Benson's Vette... he got his head on with some drunk. Never had a chance. Damn good driver, too. What a waste when somebody gets it and it ain't even their fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Needs a paint job, that's for sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Vette over there. Walt Hawkins, a real ding-a-ling. Wrapped it around a fig tree out on Mesa Vista with five kids in it. Draggin' with five kids in the car, how dumb can you get? All the ding-a-lings get it sooner or later. Maybe that's why they invented cars. To get rid of the ding-a-lings. Tough when they take someone with them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never had a wreck though--you told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I come pretty close a couple of times. Almost rolled once. So far I've been quick enough to stay out of here. The quick and the dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bet you're the fastest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never been beaten--lot of punks have tried. See that '41 Ford there? Used to be the fastest wheels in the valley. I never got a chance to race old Earl. He got his in '55 in the hairiest crash ever happened around here. He was racing a '54 Chevy, bored and loaded, out on the old Oakdale Highway and every damn kid in town was out there. The Chevy lost its front wheel doing about 85. The idiot had torched the spindles to lower the front end and it snapped right off. He slammed bam into the Ford and then they both of them crashed into a row of cars and all those kids watchin! Jesus, eight kids killed including both drivers, looked like a battlefield. Board of Education was so impressed they filmed it. Show it now in Drivers Education, maybe you'll see it. Anyway, since then street racing's gone underground. No spectators, I mean. Too bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd love to see you race.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on! None of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whadaya mean? I'm the one who's supposed to say that. Whadaya afraid of? I'll keep it above the waist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny... (he looks at her for a moment) Who knows, in a few years--but not now, bunny rabbit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bunny rabbit! Oh brother, you are such a drip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, open the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you say "Carol's not a bunny, she's a foxy little tail."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Carol's not a rabbit, she's a foxy little tail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You say the cutest things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Sneakin' around with the Wolfman, Baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Curt is sitting on the hood of a parked De Soto watching a row of televisions in the window of an appliance store. Twelve silent images of Ricky Nelson on "Ozzie and Harriet" glow in the dark showroom. Music from passing cars rises and fades as they cruise behind Curt. The Wolfman can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Wolfman howls and the Platters wail into the "Great Pretender." Curt sings along, mouthing the words. Then somebody walks in front of Curt. Curt pays no attention, then sense the presence of another guy. Soon he realizes that he is being surrounded by a group of three hoods. They slink up from all sides wearing car coats with the name "PHAROAHS" embroidered across the back. Curt looks them over--they all watch the silent tv's. One of them, without turning, talks to Curt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's silence. Curt looks uneasy and slides quietly off the De Soto. Curt sticks his hands in his pockets and starts slowly down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ants (a tall, ghoulish-looking kid who probably got his name from the scar across his face which has recently been stitched to look like a party of ants marching across his cheek) brings Curt back gently. Joe is bent over looking across the hood of the De Soto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe unbends and lightly punches Curt on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe gives him another charming punch on the shoulder. The others have left the tv's and are watching Curt now, looking puzzled and pained at the scratch on the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt turns and laughs at Ants' suggestion. He laughs and laughs until he realizes nobody else is; they are pondering the suggestion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all grin and laugh with Curt who feels better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt stops smiling again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt looks at them both, praying they're kidding. Joe looks at him, shaking his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe leads Curt gently but forcibly toward an incredible maroon '51 Merc that's been lowered and chopped so that the windows are like ominous slits and the whole machine has a submarine quality. Joe opens the door and Curt slides into the white fluffy interior. In the small back window, a metal plaque reads "PHAROAHS." The third member of the gang is Carlos, a short little kid about fifteen years old. He appears tougher than the rest with a cigarette dangling from his mouth. Joe heads for the driver's side and Ants and Carlos both go for the front passenger door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlos gives Ants a hard look and Ants backs down and climbs in the back with Curt. The Pharoah's Mercury roars out from the curb.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Oh, this is gonna strike a raw nerve, mama. Here's the Platters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whadaya doin', creep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm talking to the other fifty creeps here. You know Gil Gonzales?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gil Gonzales... no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know Gil... you oughta. You really should.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No reason... he's a friend of ours... and that's his car you're sitting on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, where ya goin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) No place. Not going any place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya must be going someplace--I mean ya left here. Bring him over here, Ants, I want to show him something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here--bend down, look here. See that? Right across there--see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so--yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You scratched it, man. Where do you get off sitting on Gil's car, huh, man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. It's not much of a scratch. I don't think he'll even--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't the size that's in question here. It's the principle. Jeez, this is tough... what should we do with ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tie him to the car and drag him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's funny (clearing his throat) Hey, you guys know Toby Juarez? He's a Pharoah, isn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Toby Juarez. Yeah, sure we know Toby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a friend of mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, good old Toby. He's a friend of yours. That's cool... we all hate his guts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh--well, I don't know him that much anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We killed him last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tied him to a car and dragged him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is going to take some thinking. You better come with us maybe. (putting his arm around Curt) Go riding with the Pharoahs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't think I can--I gotta--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know just how ya feel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shotgun!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I called it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before we picked you up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't call it for the whole night, man. I got it now. Get in the back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The radio blares "Ain't that a Shame?" as Curt sits in the back seat of the car looking very nervous. He eyes the three hoods cautiously. They are sitting super low, their eyes just visible over the windows. Then, Curt happens to look around. He does a double take. Through the narrow window he sees the Thunderbird passing in the opposite direction. Curt swivels and watches through the back window as the T-bird disappears around a corner. Then, he shakes his head. Of all the times to be trapped with the Pharoahs. On the radio the Wolfman is giving a phone operator a bad time and the Pharoahs are chuckling. As the Wolfman continues on the radio, the cars pass though the night like a metallic ballet. The Pharoahs' Mercury (with Curt aboard) passes Laurie's Edsel... Inside the Edsel, Steve is driving. He puts his arm around Laurie and she leans her head on his shoulder. As the Edsel cruises by in one direction, John Milner's '32 Ford coupe rumbles by on the other side of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol is laughing like mad as the Wolfman continues. Even John has to chuckle at the mad D.J.'s raspy patter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol looks over at John and shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Who is this on the Wolfman telephone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hello, Collect...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pardon me. Your name is Colette?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Collect Call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your name is Colette Call?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, this is the Operator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you French, Operator?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a collect call for Wolfman Jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... I love you, Operator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this Wolfman Jack?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Floyd there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's for a Wolfman... Jack...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just love listening to the Wolfman. My Mom won't let me at home. Because he's a Negro, I think... anyway, he's terrific. Do you know that he just broadcasts from a plane that flies around in circles all the time? Do you think that's true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Terry drives on through the wonderful night--a blonde sitting next to him, he's feeling very bitchin'. He and Debbie are also mesmerized by the Wolfman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Floyd, I love you, Floyd. Is this you, Floyd? I cannot look on thee, love took my hand... and smiling did reply, who made the eyes but I. Floyd, reach out and touch my soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Even Curt has to laugh at the Wolfman--despite his situation. Little Carlos sits in the front seat and looks over at Joe who's driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the back seat, Ants nods in agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Ants' nose starts twitching and he looks over at Curt suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt tries to smile but looks pretty guilty. Then Joe looks around from the front seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt scoots down to a level even with Ants. Ants is staring at him and grinning evilly. Then they hear an incredible roar, and they all turn to see Bob Falfa's black '55 Chevy pass by. Falfa has a new girl with him this time, a lovely redhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt nods and tries to join in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carlos and Ants look at him. Like nobody asked him to open his mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Your party's ready, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean Floyd? Hello, is this Floyd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hello, is this Matilda?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it ain't honey--bye!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You tell her, Wolfman. He's my man. When I graduate, I'm gonna be a Wolfman. Hey, you know he broadcasts out of Mexico someplace?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he don't. I seen the station right outside of town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just a clearing station, man. So he can fool the cops. He blasts that thing all the way around the world. It's against the law, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, man--they'll never catch the Wolfman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, man, who cut the cheese?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He who smelt it, dealt it. (looking at Curt in the back) Hey, creep, scoot down. Sitting up like that, it wrecks the lines of the car, you know what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's that badass Chevy again. Look at he snatch he's got with him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, man, he looks like a whimp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably is. Whimps get all the snatch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Milner ain't gonna beat that. His time has come. He's getting old. He ain't as fast as he used to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Milner may not be as fast a he used to be--and having a little teeny-bopper with him isn't helping matters. He looks over at Carol. She's moved closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol slides back to her side. But as they glide along, Carol watches John. She's moon-eyed and flipped over him. John deftly down-shifts as he approaches a light and then accelerates through the gears with a "race" expertise. There's a honk and John and Carol look over to see a '60 Cadillac full of girls laughing at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John nods modestly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl suddenly launches a water balloon, which John ducks deftly, the tumescent missile catching Carol full in the face. The girls roar off. John cracks up as Carol blinks away the water, not believing what's happened. She wipes her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John tries to control himself, but can't.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You got two seconds to get your ass over in the corner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, I won't rape you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a bitchin' car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In fact, we're gonna give you our special prize for having the neatest car around. You want me to give it to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If the prize is you, honey, I'm a ready Teddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well get bent turkey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, very funny. What a chop. Ha ha. Quit laughing!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's catch 'em at the light. Then you jump out and flatten their tires.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait a--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just do what I say!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yezz, bozz....
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carol jumps out of the car as John stops the car in the right hand lane next to the Cadillac. As Chuck Berry wails "Johnny B. Goode," they go into action. The girls in the Cadillac recognize John as one of their victims and quickly roll up all windows and lock their doors. John starts pulling the stems from the front tires, sinking the car. Carol starts around the car with the shaving cream, spraying all their windows with the foamy lather. Carol is having a great time and John is laughing as they continue their guerrilla attack. They finish and jump back in the coupe. The light turns green and John takes off, leaving the Cadillac stranded at the intersection, covered with shaving cream. Traffic begins to back up... horns begin to honk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crickets chirp under the full moon. We hear "I Only Have Eyes for You" playing as the Chevy slowly comes to a stop in an isolated spot along the irrigation canal. Terry gets out of the car, pops the top off two cokes and pours half of them into the canal. He hums, refilling them with bourbon. He goes back to the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her one of the bottles and takes a long drink out of the other. He grabs the steering wheel for support and his eyes begin to water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry takes a smaller sip this time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry chokes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He suddenly grabs at her, putting his arms around her. She's caught off-guard and tries to move away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry immediately lets go of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her coke on the floor. She unfastens the chain holding her sweater together and takes it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, she grabs him and pulls him down on top of herself. She kisses him madly. At first he's surprised, but then gets the hang of it. They begin to neck passionately, encountering many obstacles in the cramped front seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they roll around, a couple of guys walk by the car laughing. Terry manages to sit up and watches them go off into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debbie pulls him back down on top of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both get out of the car. Terry gets the blanket out of the trunk. They walk along a path next to the moonlit canal. Debbie carries their drinks for them. They left the radio on and Wolfman's voice can be heard as he takes another call.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tootie fruiti all ruti... It's Super Cola!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a... a little... strong, I think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (drinking) It's the living end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeaah, I guess it wasn't mixed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow, it's pretty tonight. It's a perfect night to go horseback riding-- I was going with a guy once who had a horse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah? I used to have a couple of horses myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I used them for hunting. I do a lot of hunting. Deer mostly, although I got a couple of bear last year. Yep, they were good ponies--hunting ponies. I had to train 'em special, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still have 'em? We could go for a ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I had to sell 'em. To get these wheels... and a jeep. I also have a jeep pick-up, with four-wheel drive. It's got a gun rack. And I use that for hunting mostly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you kill little animals? I think that's terrible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, yeah, I figure with bears, though, it's either me or them... You know, I think you're really neat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, jeez, I'm sorry. I don't know what got into me--I didn't mean to-- maybe it's the booze or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There--now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ow--you pinched me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me get my head over here--okay, now you get up--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ow--my leg, my leg. Ow, watch it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ummm, I just love tuck 'n roll upholstery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Geez, it's like Grand Central Station around here. Why don't we go someplace else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, come on. They won't come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute. I got a blanket in the back. Why don't we go over into the field?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How old are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm thirteen, how old are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm only fourteen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, boy, I love you, Wolfman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (singing over) "Wolfman Jack."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, now we gonna do the weather for all the valleys and the mountain tops. Gonna be hot... about 200 degrees in Merced, 400 degrees out in Fresno, and I know we're gonna have about 500 degrees up around the valley somewhere. You got the Wolfman Jack Show.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the Silhouettes yip-yip-yip-yip into "Get a Job," we see the mysterious white Thunderbirds cruise by and disappear. The Pharoahs' Mercury turns into the parking lot of a a miniature golf course. The doors open and the Pharoahs exit. There's a pause, then Ants reaches into the car and pulls Curt out also. The Pharoahs saunter into the miniature golf compound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe gives Curt a gentle push and they go inside. The golf course is empty, except for a couple of ugly girls putting around in the far corner. Under a trellis, Curt and Joe enter as the Pharoahs fool around with the candy machine, pinball games, "Check Your Weight," and "Air Corps Gunner" games, pretending to play with them.  Joe looks around, whistling again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly the Pharoahs go into action, jimmying locks, pounding coin returns, pulling out plugs, prying open change boxes and stuffing looses coins into their pockets. Joe smiles at Curt, who looks sick again, involved now in a robbery. Ants is sitting in a "Rocket to the Moon" ride, pounding on it unsuccessfully when suddenly it starts. Ants starts bouncing up and down looking dumber than usual. He swears at Rocket to the Moon under his breath--suddenly a screen door slams. The Pharoahs turn. A man in an undershirt stands by the "Get Your Balls Here" booth, regarding them warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Pharoahs can't think of anything right away. Ants bounces noisily in the "Rocket to the Moon." The Pharoahs are all looking to Joe for guidance. Joe for his part is mumbling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man looks at Curt, surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Pharoahs don't know what's happening yet. Curt walks over to Mr. Gordon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gordon looks skeptical, then Curt smiles at him. Then Mr. Gordon smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs nervously. The Pharoahs laugh. Everybody's happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gordon looks puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads Curt toward the screen door. Curt looks around at the Pharoahs, who are slowly starting to work again pilfering the machines. Inside the small office, Curt shakes hands with Hank Anderson, who pats him on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a knock at the screen and they turn to see Joe at the screen door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt and Joe go out through the arcade toward the Mercury. They start walking faster, anxious to get away. Joe grins at Curt as they climb into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back in the office, Hank and Mr. Gordon watch the car pull out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, terrific, I love miniature golf.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't play that often really. Ah--what're we doing here then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're outta gas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't sell gas here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... but we're outta money, too. Come on, Carl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Curt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, men.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON What're you punks doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, hi. Mr. Gordon, what's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Henderson--Curt Henderson? You with these punks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are my friends. We were just...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Jeez, you guys had me scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Hey, you haven't left yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh ah--no--no, I'm not--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, I'm not leaving until tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Tomorrow. Well, listen, Hank Anderson's inside. Come in and say goodbye. You know, Hank's the one that brought your name up on the floor of the Moose Hall. You got the check, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are all proud of you, Curt. The Moose Scholarship couldn't have gone to a better boy. And if there's anything we can do, let us know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Yeah, you'll stay in touch by letter, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, we're all done out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON All done? What--what's he mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, he means, we're all done having loads of fun out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Oh, well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful. You can have all the fun you want. This place is for fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Yes, it is. Thank you. Thank you both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Good luck now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before I say goodbye, Curt, I want to tell you I hope you'll be taking along with you a little piece of this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Don't forget us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I won't forget you and you won't forget me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GORDON Okay. 'Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good-bye and good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was nice to meet yuh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. What he said goes for me, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you just might make it as a Pharoah yet, boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some day he'll make a fine Moose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve's Chevy sits near the canal. The door is open and the radio blares, while Terry and Debbie are off somewhere in the weeds making out. Suddenly, a beam from a flashlight plays across the trunk. Feet approach the car as the light beam moves across the interior and stops on the vacated shoes on the front seat. The light beam continues past the empty bourbon bottle and starts int he direction of the field where Terry and Debbie are lost in the throes of passionate love. As we follow the light into the field we hear footsteps. As the darkened figure approaches the couple, we see the light go out and catch a gleam of silver in the moonlight as a switchblade springs open! Terry reacts to the sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him and he forgets about the noise. The figure retreats back to the Chevy, where another indistinct figure waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry and Debbie are resting in the field, listening to the radio in the distance. A car engine is heard starting up and disappearing down the canal bank. The countryside is very quiet. Only crickets and frogs are heard as Terry begins to drop off asleep. He suddenly jumps with a start.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He scrambles to the spot where the Chevy once stood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debbie comes up and watches Terry look heavenward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I heard something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) They're porking in the weeds. No sweat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The radio is gone... That means--the car is gone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no!!! OH NO!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh God--I'm sorry. But, why the car? You could have struck us with lightning or something--anything--- but not the car!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cars are seen here and there in the moonlight along the irrigation canal outside of town. In the cars radios are playing "To the Aisle," laughter can be heard in some, whispering in others. Laurie's Edsel is parked by the slow-moving water. In the front seat of the car, Steve and Laurie are making out. Laurie leans back against Steve, his arms around her, and they look out the window at the stars...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laurie's expression changes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks sullen and he smiles a little. He turns her around and gently kisses here. They begin to make out, Laurie seeming a little desperate. Steve pushes her slowly down on the seat. He moves on top of here and his hand begins to wander.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes her eyes, trying not to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to move on top of her, kissing her neck. She struggles for a few moments, then goes limp, not responding. He pulls away angrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches past him and pulls the door handle. The door swings open and she shoves Steve out. Then she starts the engine and drives away, leaving Steve standing there in the darkness. In the distance, he hears the laughter of other couples and the drifting music from their radios.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know, it doesn't make sense to leave home to look for a home, to give up a life to find a new life, to say goodbye to friends you love just to find new friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Say that again, I didn't--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what Curt said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, figures. (smiling) You must've talked his ear off trying to get him to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not true. I didn't say anything. Curt just said at dinner tonight he realized there was no big hurry. He thought he should take it easy for a while, go to J.C. and try to figure out what he wants to do with his life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds logical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. I think Curt's probably right for Curt. Not for me though. Laurie, look at me. Now you know what I want out of life. And it's just not in this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going to the airport tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve! Don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) It's our last night together for three months... come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've been through this before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to miss you so much. I need something to remember you by. You don't want me to forget you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) No...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong? You're just lying there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well go ahead, you want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're not going to remember me for anything else, why don't you go ahead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want it and you know it. Don't be so damn self-righteous with me. After those things you told me about watching your brother--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're disgusting! Get out of my car! I told you never--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out! It's not worth it. I don't care if you're leaving--now get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Terry and Debbie walk slowly along the dark canal. Terry takes a large slug of his bourbon and coke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry thinks about it and indeed it is. He looks around into the darkness and then takes Debbie's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry is slowing and he stops her. He motions for her to shut up and they listen. The wind whines across the flat valley. Ahead there is only darkness, then footsteps!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry has turned and is starting off when she grabs him by his shirt-tail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes Terry's hand and they go off behind some bushes, away from the black water. Debbie looks through the bushes, squinting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry stands with his eyes closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She edges off to get a better view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's gone. Terry starts off, taking one step, turns, takes another, turns, takes another. Suddenly Terry hears something behind him. He turns very slowly and looks... A figure is standing right behind him, silhouetted by the moon, its face obscured. Terry jumps about three feet and yells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry stops yelling, seeing that it's Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Debbie comes back through the bushes and Terry looks at her nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terry and Debbie start to walk with Steve back toward town. Terry keeps taking pulls from the bottle of bourbon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue to walk along the dark canal bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve just shrugs. The three of them go off into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway, the Goat Killer--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's talk about something else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --Whenever he strikes, he leaves a bloody goat's head near the victim. Isn't that creepy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They thought he went up to Stockton, but two nights ago they found Carlie Johnson and Don White right here by the canal all hacked to pieces and--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who do you think'll take the regionals this--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --not only were there bloody goats' heads, but he had switched all the parts of their bodies around. You know putting her arms on him and his legs on--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a second. Did you hear...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think it's the Goat Killer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) No! I mean, no. Listen, I'll go for help, you stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, we'll hide in the field.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe if it's the Goat Killer he'll get somebody and we'll see the whole thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to see the whole thing. Especially if it's us he--oh, why me? I'm going to look lousy with your legs and a goat's head and--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shhh--he's stopped. I can't see him very--I think he's coming this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, as long as he's not--Debbie! Debbie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Terry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who, me? Why me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd you go, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, don't go off again. Come on, let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're you doing out here? Hey, where's my rod?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (choking) Um, oh, did I introduce you? This is Debbie. Debbie, this is Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what about my car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Um... I'ts in the garage. I put it in the garage for safe keeping. I mean... I don't want to take any chances with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Yeah. It's a good thing too. 'Cause somebody stole our car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? That's terrible. What kind was it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gee, ah, where's Laurie, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess we broke up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You broke up? Bull!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The coupe makes an eccentric swerve as it cruises along the main drag. Inside, Carol is looking at the gear-shift knob that she's taken off the shift arm as they listen to "Do You Want to Dance?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ignores her, and finally his silence makes her take a small round knob out of her pocket and put it back on the shifter where it belongs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John sighs, wondering if he'll ever get rid of her. He looks back at something in the rear view mirror. He speeds up and checks the mirror again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carol looks scared and grabs onto the dash. John suddenly hits the brakes. The deuce coupe noses down and Bob Falfa's Chevy has to swerve abruptly to avoid a crash. Falfa pulls the Chevy around and alongside the coupe. He has another new girl with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through all the insults, Carol has been cracking up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John and Falfa both look at her and she sits back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both stop at a light now. Falfa roars his engine.
direction.name: direction

THe red lights start flashing and the siren wails. The patrol car shifts into gear and leaps forward. Suddenly, there's a horrendous metallic screech, the patrol car hurtles up and out, airborne for a moment--then noses down and bounces along the pavement, sending out sparks as it slides to a stop. The driver is stunned and frozen to the wheel. Holstein manages to remove his dark glasses and looks back. There, sitting quietly in the middle of the parking lot, is their trans-axle and two rear wheels. The patrol car sits on the ground at a twenty degree angle, while its engine whines impotently at top speed. On the radio, the all-seeing Wolfman gives an evil laugh--

direction.raw_text: A half dozen people are standing around in the parking lot behind the bar. Debbie is sitting on the hood of a car, swinging her legs and chewing gum. The people all seem to be watching something on the ground behind the car. Coughing is heard, then gagging, and the unmistakable sounds of someone being sick. At the back door of the bar even the cooks are looking and pointing. We hear more coughing and vomiting. A guy slides up on the hood next to Debbie.

direction.raw_text: He staggers across the lot toward Steve's Chevy! Debbie slides off the car and follows him.

direction.raw_text: Terry manages to raise his head.

direction.raw_text: The little Citroen bumps along a lonely dirt road, winding its way through dark peach orchards and wizened grape vineyards. Curt watches the deserted landscape when suddenly, the radio increases in volume and he turns it down. Then it begins to roar and distort eerily as the signal becomes more powerful. Then Curt sees it. He stops the car and gets out. He stands looking at an isolated white frame house hitting in the moonlight. Curt looks up at a spidery radio antenna that rises toward the stars, its black wires humming in the stillness. Curt starts up the gravel walk to the door. Under the glare of a naked spotlight, he sees a small intercom which plays soft Rock and Roll. He hesitates, then pushes a buzzer. He pushes it again and finally a voice comes over the intercom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A buzzer interrupts him and the door opens an inch. Curt pushes it open slowly--no one is there. A little scared, he goes inside and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Yeah, who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's--I want to talk to the Wolfman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Wolfman ain't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but I got to get in touch with him. I got something to give him before--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't take no deliveries after eight. Come back tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I can't. I want to ask him something that--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dedications by phone is Diamond 75044. Wolfman Top 40 is Box 13, Chula Vista. Wolfman Sweatshirts is Wolf Enterprises, Bakersfield. 'Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, I got a right to talk to him. I listened to him every night for as long--for twelve years almost. I know him and it's personal and it'll only take a minute and I bet Wolfman would be upset if he knew a friend couldn't get in touch with--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Curt walks slowly down a dark eerie corridor, passing strangely lit rooms with electronic generators, humming dynamos and glassed-off booths filled with flashing electronic apparatus. Curt goes through this other-worldly maze until he comes to a small, dimly lit control booth. A figure inside is barely visible through the reflections in the double glass windows. The figure turns and walks up to the window. Curt backs off a bit. A face stares at him--long hair greased in a ducktail, a short chinbeard. Then he speaks, his voice filtering strangely through a hidden speaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the window, Curt can be seen but no sound is heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt walks around through a few more glass doors and ends up in the booth with the manager. The manager sits down and leans back, turning a fan to blow on his large chest. He's a large, friendly looking man; he wears a Hawaiian shirt. He sucks on a popsicle. Curt stands awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The manager leans forward and picks up a spool of tape. He holds it up as a magician would for audience inspection, then puts it on a machine. A record is about to end. As it does the manager punches some buttons and the record segues into a Wolfman howl and then the distinctive Wolfman voice takes over. The manager adjusts the monitor volume down and sucks his popsicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The station manager smiles at Curt, who is watching the tape and blinking lights of the large console.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt sits down, undecided about leaving and upset about not being able to get in touch with the lovely creature he saw earlier that night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt looks at him a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt nods and stands. The manager swivels around and punches some buttons, putting on a commercial. He turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes the manager's hand, then wipes it on his pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt goes out the door. He starts back out through the maze of windows and electronic machines. Echoing throughout the rooms, the Wolfman's raucous voice follows Curt. The Wolfman howls and Curt turns. Through the maze of glass, shifting like prisms, he sees the station manager sitting by the mike--howling! Then, he laughs and howls again, starting to sing a song called "Bluebirds on My Dingaling," pounding out the rhythm on the console.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He backs away, leaving the Wolfman, who's on his feet now, screaming out the end of the song, dancing by himself in the little glass room, from which his voice radiates out through the night and around the world...

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm supposed to go to college back East tomorrow. And I don't know if I'm gonna go.

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, it's early in the morning. Now, I can't really talk for the Wolfman. But I think if he was here he'd tell you to get your ass in gear. Now, no offense to your home town here, but this place ain't exactly the hub of the universe, if you know what I mean. And well--I'll tell you this much--the Wolfman does come in here now and then, with tapes, to check up on me, you know, and when I hear the stories he got about the places he goes. Hell, here I sit while there's a big beautiful world out there, don't ya know. Wolfman comes in last time talking about some exotic jungle country, handing me cigars he says was rolled on the naked thighs of brown beauties. The Wolfman been everywhere and he seen everything. He got so many stories, so many memories. And here I sit sucking on popsicles.

direction.raw_text: John's '32 yellow deuce coupe and Falfa's black '55 Chevy are waiting side by side on a long, straight country road, their front wheels resting on a weather-beaten starting line. The sky is getting lighter as the radio plays "Green Onions." There are about six to eight other cars parked off the road to watch the race. Everything is quiet now, only the crickets ignoring the solemnity of the scene, and still singing. Terry jumps out of John's car, John hands him the flashlight and he takes up a position in front of the two cars. John looks over at Falfa, who's arguing with Laurie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John settles back in the driver's seat and positions his hand on the gear-shift, which we see is wrapped with rags because of the missing knob. Both drivers start revvin' their engines; the tension builds. Terry looks nervous, the engines start to scream and Terry, his hands shaking on the flashlight, manages to flash it on. Both cars roar off the starting line, tires smoking and screaming. Terry has his hands over his head and is coughing in a cloud of smoke as they pass. John beats Falfa off the line. Out on the road, as they hit third gear, the cars are almost neck and neck. Inside Falfa's car, Laurie looks scared to death. Falfa looks insane as he tromps it. John hits fourth at about eighty-five. Falfa does likewise-- but starts to fish-tail. Laurie closes her eyes, almost crying-- Falfa regains control nervously. Falfa's engine is winding out incredibly and he begins to get the edge on John. The cars rocket through the dawn light along the flashing white line until suddenly Falfa's car blows a tire, his front wheel slips off and the car shoots off into a tomato field, hits an irrigation ditch and begins flipping over wildly in a horrifying cloud of dust and smoke-- John sees the Chevy leaving the road and screams to a halt, swimming through an unbelievable U-turn and high tailing it back to the crash site. He is out of the car like a bullet, running across the dirty cloddy field. The crash car is beginning to burn in the engine compartment and John is panicked. Meanwhile, the spectators have arrived, including Steve, who jumps from his car and is running across the field. Steve and John arrive at the fire at approximately the same time. They stop, the flames are getting higher, burning up into the trees now. Steve looks around wildly--he sees John and goes at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a couple of swings at John, who finally manages to tackle him around the waist. They both get up looking at the flaming wreckage. Then John moves around the side, crouching, trying to see past the flames--suddenly, he stands and motions to Steve to come over. They both circle the wreck. Around behind the flaming car Falfa is standing in a state of shock watching the car go up in smoke, while Laurie is circling him, screaming and beating him with her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She beats at him, crying hysterically. Steve runs over and grabs her, pulling her away. She fights at Steve, too, not knowing what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Standing in the early light, Steve holds her. She throws her arms around him as the crowd develops along the irrigation ditch to watch the flaming car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John looks at Falfa who's shaking his head, watching the car dissolve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls him off by the neck of the shirt and when they're a few yards off, Falfa's '55 Chevy does blow--exploding like a small A-bomb, blowing it into Modesto history. Back on the road, John is heading toward his car, its engine still running, its door open. Terry runs up, trotting alongside John like a puppy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John stops by the open door of the deuce coupe. Terry stares at him and squints against the rising sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John nods, then looks up at Terry. His face is glowing, his glasses are smashed and his lip is swollen. John smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John climbs in the car. Terry yawns and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He climbs in too, and the deuce coupe drives off slowly as the sun rises over the ploughed fields and on the radio we hear "Only You."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey--Laurie, what in the hell are you doing in there? Is she gonna ride with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind your own business, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, she's with me. You worry about yourself, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stupid sonofabitch, she was in that car! Why did you have--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said I didn't--you lousy greasy jerk! You coulda killed me--what's wrong with you. You clubfoot...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, no. Please, don't come near me. No, please. I think I'm gonna be sick. Oh, Steven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Laurie, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Steven! Oh, Steven, please, don't leave me. Don't leave me, Steven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't bear it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, before she blows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeez, did you show him! He'll probably never even get in a car again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was faster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was beautiful, John. Just beauti-- what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was losin', man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had me, man. He was pullin' away from me just before he crashed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You saw it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you creamed him, from right off the line. The guy never had a chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit, Toad. The man had me. He was beating me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, I don't know what you're talking about. It was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. That guy, he might as well get a wheelchair and roll himself home. Man, you got... you got the bitchinist car in the Valley. You'll always be number one, John. You're the greatest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at your glasses, man. (shaking his head) Okay, Toad. We'll take 'em all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll take em... let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, what a night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Curt sleeps in the little car as the sky grows lighter over the empty parking lot. The phone is ringing in the booth. It continues to ring. Finally Curt becomes aware of it and opens his eyes. It takes him a moment to remember. Then, panicked, he jumps from the car and rushes to the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A soft sexy female voice is on the other end of the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But there's a click as she hangs up. Curt looks at the phone a moment, then also hangs up. From the car radio, he hears the Wolfman making kissing noises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then the Spaniels duh-duh-duh-duh-duh into "Goodnight Sweetheart."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, hello, hello!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Curt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... this is Curt, who is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who were you expecting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you drive a white T-Bird?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A white '56. I saw you on Third Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you? How do you know me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) It's important to me. You're the most perfect, beautiful creature I've ever seen and I don't know anything about you. Could we meet someplace?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cruise Third Street every night. Maybe I'll see you again tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm leaving... in a couple of hours. Where are you from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Curt...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name? At least tell me your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Curt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a second! Wait a second!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Little kiss on your ear. Good night, sweetheart. I'll see you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: prop airliner is warming up its engines as it waits to take off from a small country airport. There aren't too many people around. Just Curt and his friends and family seeing him off. Curt stands with a kindly-looking couple in their fifties. He hugs his mother and shakes hands with his dad. Then, Curt moves to his friends. He shakes Steve's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt hugs his sister. Laurie holds on to him for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt goes to Terry and John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curt smiles at Terry, who has a bandage on his forehead. Curt looks at John and they don't seem to know what to say. Finally, John gives Curt a little slap on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks toward the plane and they all wave. He looks around as he goes up the steps carrying a small bag and a portable radio. The stewardess smiles as he passes her. Above the door of the plane it reads RADAR EQUIPPED. Curt looks back again, then goes inside. The plane takes off down the runway and then climbs up into the sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, same to you. And I better see you there next year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah, I'll be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See ya later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye 'bye, Curt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So long, guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, stay cool, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah--don't do anything I wouldn't do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see ya, buddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, you probably think you're a big shot, goin' off like this--but you're still a punk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, John. So long.
dialogue.name: dialogue
